The New York Times article from 2000: The expert's verdict mentions that The New York Times published an article in 2000 discussing the difficulty of finding unclaimed screen names on internet services. This article supports the claim that it is challenging to secure a desired Twitter handle, especially for celebrities.
Widely shared screenshot on social media: The expert's verdict mentions a screenshot that was widely shared on social media. This screenshot supposedly showed musician Sean P. Diddy Combs' attempts to secure the Twitter handle @SeanCombs from a comb-seller named Sean's Combs. The popularity and circulation of this screenshot contribute to the authenticity of the claim.
Fake Twitter conversation: The expert's verdict clarifies that the online conversation depicted in the screenshot never took place. It explains that the screenshot was created for a 2014 article on the "Funny or Die" humor website. This aspect verifies that the screenshot is fictional and not an actual exchange between Diddy and the comb-seller.
Additional fictional images: The expert's verdict mentions that the "Funny or Die" article included five additional images showing Diddy's failed attempts to secure other Twitter handles. These images further support the claim that the screenshot is part of a fictional story and not a genuine interaction between Diddy and the comb-seller.
